New Records: Christian Eriksen became the oldest player with at least four chances created in consecutive European Championship games, since a 33-year-old Andrea Pirlo in 2012
Key Match Events: Trent Alexander-Arnold's experiment in midfield continued, but he played more chances for England than anyone else and also played the most line-breaking passes in the final third
Harry Kane struggled with fitness and was substituted early in the second half
England dropped deep and allowed Denmark to come back into the game
Pierre-Emile HÃ¸jbjerg was handed the official player of the match award
Pre-Game Insights: Russell backing England, or at least he was
George Russell thought England could win the tournament and praised their squad and Gareth Southgate
Christian Eriksen thought Denmark should have won the game, but it was better than their previous performance
Post-Match Reflections: Gareth Southgate explained that he wanted to get Conor Gallagher on the pitch to press better and that Trent Alexander-Arnold's experiment was an attempt to find a natural replacement for Kalvin Phillips
Harry Kane thought England struggled with and without the ball and that they needed to find a way to get the pressure on
Kyle Walker said that sometimes you have to manage the game in tournaments and that England didn't lose, but could have done better
Miscellaneous Highlights: The final games of Group C will be resolved on Sunday night, with England vs Slovenia and Denmark vs Serbia
England are top of the group with four points from two games
The stats suggest Denmark shaded the game, but it felt more one-sided in the stadium
England had 17 free-kicks to Denmark's five, but it was an awful performance from a Southgate England team
Others: The England performance was significantly short of their opening win over Serbia, and Gareth Southgate's team will be in for a bit of criticism
The result is far from disastrous, but the performance was troubling from an England perspective
